Award.AwardTitle: IRES Collaborative Research: Student-Assisted Global Exoplanet Search (SAGES)
Award.AbstractNarration:
IRES-SAGES will train US undergraduate students to help discover and characterize exoplanets, planets outside our solar system. Students will travel abroad to receive mentorship from international experts in the most important observational techniques for exoplanet studies. The students will then bring their acquired skills and research products back to the US where they will continue their investigations, train fellow students, disseminate their findings, and develop outreach activities for their local communities and K-12 schools. The students? research will target gas giant exoplanets in close orbits ? so-called ?hot Jupiters? ? around especially bright stars. Although thousands of exoplanets have been discovered, nearly all of our direct in-depth knowledge of exoplanet properties comes from a handful of hot Jupiters orbiting bright stars. Both the students? home institutions and the foreign institutions they will visit are members of the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope (KELT) project, a global collaboration with a proven record of discovering these important planets. IRES-SAGES will produce US citizens who are both globally engaged and more rigorously prepared for employment in physics- and space-related industries, advance the field of astrophysics research, promote national and international interests in space exploration, and improve scientific literacy in the US through outreach activities. The recruitment of IRES-SAGES students will target demographic groups traditionally underrepresented in the physical science fields.

Surveys for exoplanet transits ? dimmings of a star when one of its planets partially eclipses it ? have been largely limited to stars fainter than tenth magnitude. KELT was created to search for planets transiting brighter stars through the use of telescopes specially designed to prevent image saturation. Only about two dozen hot Jupiters transiting stars brighter than tenth magnitude are known, but they are responsible for nearly all of the published literature on exoplanetary atmospheres, direct thermal emission, and spin-orbit alignment. Until more transiting super-Earths and Neptunes are discovered around bright stars and technology advances to the point where we can investigate them more thoroughly, hot Jupiters transiting bright stars remain the best sites for individual exoplanet exploration. KELT has discovered several of these planets through its global network of observatories and astronomers with different key specialties. IRES-SAGES will leverage this network to train US students in the discovery and characterization of these planets, as well as the wider range of planet types targeted by the microlensing, radial velocity, and transit programs of KELT?s foreign partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How many planets exist out there beyond our own solar system?  What are they like, and can we see them from Earth?  In search of answers, the modern study of exoplanets commenced not too long ago when in 1995 a planet was discovered in orbit around another Sun-like star for the first time.  It is called 51 Pegasi b, and is a hot Jupiter-like planet located some 50 light years (300 trillion miles) from Earth.  The discovery of 51 Pegasi b was recently recognized for its significance with the awarding of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics.  An additional 4200+ exoplanets have since been discovered, out of an estimated total of at least 100 billion exoplanets in our Milky Way Galaxy alone.  Participants of this NSF-funded project directly contributed observations and analyses to the discovery of several of the newfound exoplanets and participated in the characterization of hundreds more.

Most of this project's exoplanet discoveries were achieved in collaboration with the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope (KELT) exoplanet discovery project.  KELT worked with an international collaboration of observatories that focused primarily on discovering and characterizing large planets orbiting close to bright stars.  Such exoplanets are the best laboratories we currently have for studying exoplanetary atmospheres, direct exoplanetary thermal emission, and (mis)alignments between an exoplanet's orbit and the spin of its host star.  A major achievement of the KELT network was the discovery of KELT-9b, an ultra-hot Jupiter-like planet in a nearly polar orbit around a hot and rapidly-rotating star.

The KELT exoplanet discoveries that resulted, in part, from this project's contributions include KELT-16b, KELT-18b, and KELT-23Ab, among others.  KELT-16b has an ultra-short orbital period (less than 1 day) and is so close to its host star that it could soon undergo tidal disruption - getting ripped apart by the star's gravity.  KELT-18b has a very puffy atmosphere making it an excellent target for atmospheric studies by future missions such as the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).  KELT-23Ab orbits close to the brighter of two stars that are gravitationally bound together in a very wide (>10,000 year period) binary star orbit.  KELT-16b, KELT-18b, and KELT-23Ab all fall in the class of "hot Jupiters" - they are the size of the giant planet Jupiter, but they are much hotter than Jupiter because they are much closer to their host stars than Jupiter is to the Sun.

During the final year of this project, NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) mission became active, and many in the KELT network shifted their observatories' efforts to confirming TESS exoplanet candidates.  Participants supported by this award were involved in the discovery of TESS planet TOI-257b.  TOI-257b is smaller than the KELT discoveries, and it lies farther away from its star.  TOI-257b is classified as a "warm sub-Saturn," making it a rare and important addition to list of currently known exoplanets.

Making valuable contributions to the advancement of exoplanetary science was not the sole intent or outcome of this project.  Other, broader impacts included bringing the process of scientific discovery directly to the local community, transforming astronomy education within the physics program at our Pennsylvania state-owned university, and providing upward mobility for the university's participating undergraduate students.

Our on-campus 100-seat planetarium is the venue for an active outreach program and hosts thousands of visitors each year in the form of school field trips, community group events, and public planetarium shows.  Custom content developed by this project has been well received for its personal touch by incorporating the participating students' first-hand experiences with scientific discovery into planetarium presentations.

Work done under this NSF award also led to the development of a new 200-level undergraduate course on exoplanets.  The novel course includes a weekly laboratory experience in which the students use our on-campus astronomical observatory to participate in a major international exoplanet discovery effort, as the campus observatory now serves as an active follow-up facility for NASA's TESS mission.  Students plan, conduct, and analyze telescopic observations to vet TESS planet candidates, confirm exoplanet detections, and provide measurements of characteristic parameters such as planetary radius.

Finally, this NSF award afforded our students the mentorship, training, and research experiences necessary to prepare them for competitive careers in science.  All participants traveled internationally and collaborated with exoplanet experts.  They all presented their work at national conferences and in peer-reviewed publications.  More than half of the participants are now pursuing advanced degrees in astronomy, physics, mathematics, or environmental science.  Two-thirds of the participants are members of groups underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.
